results.snippets: Google unveils Gemini 3, enhancing reasoning and problem-solving capabilities. AI-powered IVRs are replacing outdated Press 1 menus, enabling seamless conversational experiences. results.snippets: AI adoption is surging globally, with India aiming to become a leader in AI-driven healthcare and transforming unstructured health data into actionable insights. Agentic AI is revolutionizing business models by transitioning AI from a tool to an autonomous partner. Google's Gemini 3 Pro and OpenAI's GPT-5.1 Pro lead notable AI model releases, enhancing multimodal capabilities and agentic systems.

results.title: Exploring the Impact of Generative AI on the Future of News |
results.snippets: Generative AI has made significant advancements in recent years, with applications in various fields such as art, music, and writing. Researchers have developed more sophisticated models that can generate realistic images, videos, and even entire articles. However, there are also concerns about the ethics and safety of Generative AI, including issues related to bias, misinformation, and job displacement. As a result, governments and regulatory bodies are starting to take notice and develop guidelines for the responsible development and use of Generative AI.

type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"Article","name":"Exploring the Impact of Generative AI on the Future of News ","headline":"Exploring the Impact of Generative AI on the Future of News ","author":{"@type":"Person","name":"Viggy Balagopalakrishnan"},"datePublished":"2023-07-30","image":"https://hackernoon.imgix.net/images/RslbrPJJMpVSoCm5D7gzfEIZtz83-wxe3rz9.jpeg","articleSection":"artificial-intelligence","articleBody":"Last week, the that is testing an AI tool that enables news organizations to create content using AI. It is unclear what the exact capabilities of the product are but based on one comment from Google, it helps with tasks like headlines and modifying writing styles. Amidst fears of what impact this could have on journalist jobs, Google quickly put out a : New York Times reported Google clarifying statement Our goal is to give journalists the choice of using these emerging technologies in a way that enhances their work and productivity. Quite simply these tools are not intended to, and cannot, replace the essential role journalists have in reporting, creating, and fact-checking their articles. This has sparked a heated conversation about the future of news with generative AI. The companies making AI products argue that this technology will enable media organizations and journalists to be more effective, while critics contend that it could potentially harm journalist jobs, increase misinformation, and flood the market with low-quality AI-generated content. In this piece, we unpack the by exploring a few things: impact of generative AI on the future of news Types of news articles today by complexity The business of news The anatomy of producing a news article What generative AI can and cannot do well Generative AI and the Future of News — A tale of two worlds Types of news articles today by complexity There are several types of news content on the internet, each with varying levels of complexity in their production. The complexity typically arises from factors like timeliness, the amount of research required, and the story being told. The low-complexity articles include: Factual/data news (eg. article listing mortgage rates in San Francisco, article with numbers from a company’s earnings call) — these are relatively straightforward with minimal subjective opinions or perspectives. Interest-based/informational news (eg. summer recipes published on NY Times Cooking, an article explaining what the Fed interest rate means) — there is some creativity in selecting topics but the focus is more informational and catering to specific interests. Breaking news (eg. an article about a CEO resigning, an article describing an active weather event) — these are typically short articles about a rapidly unfolding event, with limited initial information and emerging facts. The include: high-complexity articles News coverage (with context, research, and facts) — these provide a more detailed explanation of news backed by research, additional context, and often interviews with people, thereby requiring more time and effort to produce; they are also extensively fact-checked. Interpretive news — this includes opinion pieces, op-eds, and analyses (like this one) that provide interpretations/perspectives/opinions on current issues; they are often subjective and require extensive research to back up the perspectives. Feature pieces — these are typically deep dives on topics that might not really be hot news right now but important issues, investigative journalism would fall in this category; these require extensive research and interviews spanning across months, and also creative storytelling. I bring up this categorization because the purpose behind and process involved in producing these two types of articles is very different, and consequently will evolve differently with the use of generative AI. With this in mind, let’s talk about how news makes money. The business of news The business of news is tricky — most news organizations operate on an ad-supported media model, and a small subset have successfully managed to pivot to subscriptions. This has major implications for the type of content a news organization produces. The businesses (NYTimes notably now gets from subscriptions) have a content strategy that’s tied directly to consumer value — focus on to make the subscription worthwhile. For example, of the types of content above, NYT primarily does news coverage (that is well-researched), interpretive news, and feature pieces for their core news offering, backed up by interest-based content like and . Some other publications like the Wall Street Journal and the Washington Post have made strides with subscriptions using a similar approach. subscription-based news ~70% of revenue high-quality content + diverse interest-based content NYT Cooking Wirecutter However, and will continue to be so for the foreseeable future. This means that they are focused on generating high engagement: more eyeballs → more ad inventory → more revenue. The strategy that has been more effective for them is (like news coverage, interpretive news) (like factual/data news, interest-based/informational news). most publications are still ad-supported augmenting high-complexity content with a ton of high volume, low-complexity content This strategy works because high-complexity content helps deliver long-term value to consumers, while the ton of low-complexity content helps . The SEO loop looks something like: high volume of content that gets clicks → search engines think your content is valuable → all of your content gets ranked higher → more eyeballs. get eyeballs as well as win the SEO game This is no criticism of the strategy and the need to play the SEO game is a necessity for ad-supported media. The reality is that — the internet disrupted how content was created and distributed (mostly through Google Search / today), and news organizations have not recovered from the impact of that disruption. There are attempts to fix the imbalance, which are still evolving — Canada/Australia passed laws that force Google/Meta to pay what’s essentially a “disruptor tax” to support good journalism, some organizations like NPR are partially supported by , and some newspapers like the Washington Post are . news media is a terrible business Meta federal funding subsidized by (generally well-meaning) billionaires All this to say — news media/journalism is an absolutely essential public utility for a well-functioning democracy but a not-so-great business. Therefore, the more self-reliant these news businesses can be (without having to depend on regulation or billionaires), the more effective they can be towards achieving their mission. Generative AI can’t solve all of these structural challenges (especially content distribution) but it can definitely make content creation more efficient without necessarily compromising on quality. The anatomy of producing a news article To understand what part of news production will generative AI have the most impact on, it’s helpful to understand the different steps involved in getting a news article published. We can break down the effort into a few sequential components: Research — finding a topic, gathering facts/data, talking to the right people for quotes or perspectives Storytelling — making sense of the research to come up with a compelling storyline Writing — turning the storyline into actual words that make an article, buttoning up the storyline, backing it up with the right data / adding supporting links Editing — improving the writing, coming up with catchier headlines, having better visuals, and fact-checking to meet standards Distribution — publishing, and distributing across channels like social media. Based on some research and also influenced by my writing experience, I estimate the effort of producing an article into something like: . Take the actual numbers with a grain of salt but they are directionally accurate. Research (30%), Storytelling (20%), Writing (20%), Editing (20%), and Distribution (10%) Now, note that — the low-complexity pieces might not need to rigorously go through all steps in the life cycle above but the high-complexity pieces do. not all formats of news articles require all of the steps As an example, this article took me ~8–9 hours to finish (so did most other articles on ), and I would like to think that my articles fall under interpretive news. If I wrote a low-complexity piece, I could probably get it done in ~2 hours. Another data point — says he can typically get a news article done in a couple of hours while a feature piece might take up to 6 months. my Substack newsletter this NYT reporter So, what can generative AI actually help with? It basically comes down to what steps in the news production process can current (and future) products do well. What generative AI can and cannot do well Here’s my take on each step. Spoiler — they are somewhat effective for writing and editing, they can be effective for research if the right products are built, and they will continue to be bad at storytelling. Research — surprisingly low capability Most current generative AI products (like ChatGPT, and Google Bard) have surprisingly low capability when it comes to Research: There are definitely certain capabilities that they are good at. For example, they are good at giving arguments for a particular point of view or providing inspiration for new topics. They are average-to-good at summarizing content and in particular, answering questions based on reading an article. For example, you can ask them to read this article and list out different steps involved in news production. However, they often produce (“hallucinations”), to what they claim is the truth, and have questionably sourced data with potential copyright infringement. See the screenshot below. factually incorrect information do not provide links/sources For a generic use case (say you want to draft an email to a future LinkedIn connection), these issues don’t matter. But when you are writing a news article, not fact-checking can severely impair your brand perception. Though the research tools can be used for directionally useful research (for example, you want to know how much market share Bing and Yahoo search have), writers/journalists still have to do additional work to find a new source to link because current tools neither provide links nor have fully accurate data. for anyone building a research product for writers, and it’s very likely that new companies will emerge here. Using cleanly sourced data + being able to provide answers with trustworthy links is a big opportunity Storytelling — low capability Generative AI’s storytelling capabilities are fairly weak today. Here’s an example: I did a bunch of research for this article, put together the research in an organized format, and asked ChatGPT to give me a storyline. See the screenshot below for results. At first glance, it looks like they “make sense”. But that’s literally all it is — it makes sense at a surface level. In reality, none of these storylines are very compelling and the research notes I provided had much more detail and nuance beyond the surface-level results provided here. You can make the argument that these are still decent, but in the context of writing an article, this was completely useless to me — at best, this was inspiration/ideas, not a storyline based on the research I submitted. If you have a low-complexity story, it will get the job done for you. If you are building a nuanced story, or have the data and need help constructing a story, current products do not get the job done. Given the high amount of subjectivity involved, I am not bullish it will get better and this will continue to be the part where writers can add the most value. Writing — medium capability If you provide current products with a detailed storyline of what you want to say, it can generate a barely decent v1 of the content. The output is still pretty cookie-cutter and it is pretty challenging to instruct the current models to craft the language in a way that it tells a story. See the screenshot for an example output after I fed ChatGPT detailed notes about the storyline for this article. At first glance, you might think it looks okay for a v1 draft. It is not — the tone isn’t right, the story doesn’t flow and it always looks like it’s been written by a bot. It’s very generic and does not articulate the story despite being fed a very specific narrative. If I published that article, you would not read it. And that’s the challenge with the writing capability today — it can work for low-complexity articles but for anything more complex, you essentially have to rewrite the whole draft. — writers don’t want to take terrible cookie-cutter versions and redo the whole thing line by line. What they would like is some form of a user interaction construct that lets a writer feed in a storyline and sequentially craft the article section by section, while giving active feedback to the AI tool. Cherry on top would be being able to customize the writing style by feeding past articles written by the same writer. The big product unlock here would be enabling effective human instruction I think the underlying models today do have the capability to do this and there is , which I believe will happen near-term. innovation needed at the UI layer Editing — medium capability Tools today have a good amount of capability to review articles, find errors and make corrections. These tools are also very good at cosmetic tasks, like coming up with ideas for catchy headlines or section titles that might perform well. However, there is still work needed at the UI layer to make this usable for editing — there are some partial solutions today like which lets you improve language and make sentences shorter / longer from within a Notion page, but it does not capture the full context of the page. ChatGPT does a good job of making edits across a full article but lacks the ability to take instructions to easily edit specific sections and also cannot support links (i.e. I give it a blurb with text that has hyperlinks, I get back text without any links). Notion AI I absolutely hate the editing part of the writing process, and I am sure several writers and journalists do as well — generative AI can most definitely minimize some of this editing grunt work near-term. Distribution — medium capability There are tools coming up here today that for example help you generate social snippets, or identify parts of your story that might go more viral. This will likely continue getting better in the future. Generative AI and the future of News — A tale of two worlds Based on the above analysis, you can see a clear duality emerging: , which require simpler research & storytelling, and can be written & edited easily, will start to be (or heavily AI-assisted). Low-complexity formats more and more AI-generated , which require more complex research and storytelling capabilities that don’t exist today, will but generative AI can bring a good amount of High-complexity formats continue to be primarily created by journalists efficiency by minimizing writing and editing gruntwork. While AI-generated low-complexity content seems bad at first glance, these articles are primarily written for SEO purposes or to augment existing high-quality content, and the race to commoditization had started much before the generative AI wave. For example, the Associated Press has been using since 2014. The upside here — this is not the kind of content journalists want to spend time creating and automating this will free up their time for high-complexity content. bots to publish articles reporting company earnings More and more high-complexity content will emerge. Research and storytelling capabilities with products today are limited, which means that the ability to . This, accelerated by AI writing and editing tools that take the grunt work out of publishing quality content, will be a big boon for journalists. construct a compelling story based on information and story-tell in a unique way will continue to be the biggest currency journalists have What about some of the concerns raised around using AI for news? Some are fair but I believe they are mostly solvable: A wave of junk SEO content — Google has that they won’t penalize AI-generated content and have gotten criticism for opening up a world of junk content, including factually incorrect articles. That’s a somewhat fair critique but I believe Google will crack down on this — not out of the goodness of their hearts but because the crux of a search product is to give users useful results. Google already has penalties for SEO hacking practices (like keyword stuffing, and link farming) and it would be easy to extend this framework to AI content. taken the stance Journalists will lose jobs — Some have brought up the concern that journalists might lose jobs, or be in a less advantageous position (like writers in Hollywood who are currently on strike); the big difference here is that while there are a large number of writers in Hollywood, newsroom employment in the US since 2008, not because we don’t need journalists but because news is a bad business; Generative AI can help fix the economics of the business while continuing to empower journalists do what they love. has fallen 26% Conclusion I am by no means an AI maximalist and I absolutely think there are real risks to AI that need to be addressed as we scale the technology. However, I think it’s important to analyze every AI-impacted market/situation separately and not bundle them into one big AI-impact problem. In the case of news, generative AI can tremendously improve the economics of news businesses. The products are not there today — there is a clear need for AI products that thoughtfully solve writers’ needs without a brute-force, chat-based, language model interface, but I’m confident these will emerge near-term. Low-complexity writing will be more and more AI generated and that’s okay — it can help companies run an efficient SEO machine, while journalists (assisted by AI for grunt work) bring to life a lot more high complexity content that elevates the public discourse. Thank you for reading! type="application/json">{"props":{"pageProps":{"data":{"pageLang":"en","datePublished":"2023-07-30","slug":"exploring-the-impact-of-generative-ai-on-the-future-of-news","articleBody":"Last week, the that is testing an AI tool that enables news organizations to create content using AI. It is unclear what the exact capabilities of the product are but based on one comment from Google, it helps with tasks like headlines and modifying writing styles. Amidst fears of what impact this could have on journalist jobs, Google quickly put out a : New York Times reported Google clarifying statement Our goal is to give journalists the choice of using these emerging technologies in a way that enhances their work and productivity. Quite simply these tools are not intended to, and cannot, replace the essential role journalists have in reporting, creating, and fact-checking their articles. This has sparked a heated conversation about the future of news with generative AI. The companies making AI products argue that this technology will enable media organizations and journalists to be more effective, while critics contend that it could potentially harm journalist jobs, increase misinformation, and flood the market with low-quality AI-generated content. In this piece, we unpack the by exploring a few things: impact of generative AI on the future of news Types of news articles today by complexity The business of news The anatomy of producing a news article What generative AI can and cannot do well Generative AI and the Future of News — A tale of two worlds Types of news articles today by complexity There are several types of news content on the internet, each with varying levels of complexity in their production. The complexity typically arises from factors like timeliness, the amount of research required, and the story being told. The low-complexity articles include: Factual/data news (eg. article listing mortgage rates in San Francisco, article with numbers from a company’s earnings call) — these are relatively straightforward with minimal subjective opinions or perspectives. Interest-based/informational news (eg. summer recipes published on NY Times Cooking, an article explaining what the Fed interest rate means) — there is some creativity in selecting topics but the focus is more informational and catering to specific interests. Breaking news (eg. an article about a CEO resigning, an article describing an active weather event) — these are typically short articles about a rapidly unfolding event, with limited initial information and emerging facts. The include: high-complexity articles News coverage (with context, research, and facts) — these provide a more detailed explanation of news backed by research, additional context, and often interviews with people, thereby requiring more time and effort to produce; they are also extensively fact-checked. Interpretive news — this includes opinion pieces, op-eds, and analyses (like this one) that provide interpretations/perspectives/opinions on current issues; they are often subjective and require extensive research to back up the perspectives. Feature pieces — these are typically deep dives on topics that might not really be hot news right now but important issues, investigative journalism would fall in this category; these require extensive research and interviews spanning across months, and also creative storytelling. I bring up this categorization because the purpose behind and process involved in producing these two types of articles is very different, and consequently will evolve differently with the use of generative AI. With this in mind, let’s talk about how news makes money. The business of news The business of news is tricky — most news organizations operate on an ad-supported media model, and a small subset have successfully managed to pivot to subscriptions. This has major implications for the type of content a news organization produces. The businesses (NYTimes notably now gets from subscriptions) have a content strategy that’s tied directly to consumer value — focus on to make the subscription worthwhile. For example, of the types of content above, NYT primarily does news coverage (that is well-researched), interpretive news, and feature pieces for their core news offering, backed up by interest-based content like and . Some other publications like the Wall Street Journal and the Washington Post have made strides with subscriptions using a similar approach. subscription-based news ~70% of revenue high-quality content + diverse interest-based content NYT Cooking Wirecutter However, and will continue to be so for the foreseeable future. This means that they are focused on generating high engagement: more eyeballs → more ad inventory → more revenue. The strategy that has been more effective for them is (like news coverage, interpretive news) (like factual/data news, interest-based/informational news). most publications are still ad-supported augmenting high-complexity content with a ton of high volume, low-complexity content This strategy works because high-complexity content helps deliver long-term value to consumers, while the ton of low-complexity content helps . The SEO loop looks something like: high volume of content that gets clicks → search engines think your content is valuable → all of your content gets ranked higher → more eyeballs. get eyeballs as well as win the SEO game This is no criticism of the strategy and the need to play the SEO game is a necessity for ad-supported media. The reality is that — the internet disrupted how content was created and distributed (mostly through Google Search / today), and news organizations have not recovered from the impact of that disruption. There are attempts to fix the imbalance, which are still evolving — Canada/Australia passed laws that force Google/Meta to pay what’s essentially a “disruptor tax” to support good journalism, some organizations like NPR are partially supported by , and some newspapers like the Washington Post are . news media is a terrible business Meta federal funding subsidized by (generally well-meaning) billionaires All this to say — news media/journalism is an absolutely essential public utility for a well-functioning democracy but a not-so-great business. Therefore, the more self-reliant these news businesses can be (without having to depend on regulation or billionaires), the more effective they can be towards achieving their mission. Generative AI can’t solve all of these structural challenges (especially content distribution) but it can definitely make content creation more efficient without necessarily compromising on quality. The anatomy of producing a news article To understand what part of news production will generative AI have the most impact on, it’s helpful to understand the different steps involved in getting a news article published. We can break down the effort into a few sequential components: Research — finding a topic, gathering facts/data, talking to the right people for quotes or perspectives Storytelling — making sense of the research to come up with a compelling storyline Writing — turning the storyline into actual words that make an article, buttoning up the storyline, backing it up with the right data / adding supporting links Editing — improving the writing, coming up with catchier headlines, having better visuals, and fact-checking to meet standards Distribution — publishing, and distributing across channels like social media. Based on some research and also influenced by my writing experience, I estimate the effort of producing an article into something like: . Take the actual numbers with a grain of salt but they are directionally accurate. Research (30%), Storytelling (20%), Writing (20%), Editing (20%), and Distribution (10%) Now, note that — the low-complexity pieces might not need to rigorously go through all steps in the life cycle above but the high-complexity pieces do. not all formats of news articles require all of the steps As an example, this article took me ~8–9 hours to finish (so did most other articles on ), and I would like to think that my articles fall under interpretive news. If I wrote a low-complexity piece, I could probably get it done in ~2 hours. Another data point — says he can typically get a news article done in a couple of hours while a feature piece might take up to 6 months. my Substack newsletter this NYT reporter So, what can generative AI actually help with? It basically comes down to what steps in the news production process can current (and future) products do well. What generative AI can and cannot do well Here’s my take on each step. Spoiler — they are somewhat effective for writing and editing, they can be effective for research if the right products are built, and they will continue to be bad at storytelling. Research — surprisingly low capability Most current generative AI products (like ChatGPT, and Google Bard) have surprisingly low capability when it comes to Research: There are definitely certain capabilities that they are good at. For example, they are good at giving arguments for a particular point of view or providing inspiration for new topics. They are average-to-good at summarizing content and in particular, answering questions based on reading an article. For example, you can ask them to read this article and list out different steps involved in news production. However, they often produce (“hallucinations”), to what they claim is the truth, and have questionably sourced data with potential copyright infringement. See the screenshot below. factually incorrect information do not provide links/sources For a generic use case (say you want to draft an email to a future LinkedIn connection), these issues don’t matter. But when you are writing a news article, not fact-checking can severely impair your brand perception. Though the research tools can be used for directionally useful research (for example, you want to know how much market share Bing and Yahoo search have), writers/journalists still have to do additional work to find a new source to link because current tools neither provide links nor have fully accurate data. for anyone building a research product for writers, and it’s very likely that new companies will emerge here. Using cleanly sourced data + being able to provide answers with trustworthy links is a big opportunity Storytelling — low capability Generative AI’s storytelling capabilities are fairly weak today. Here’s an example: I did a bunch of research for this article, put together the research in an organized format, and asked ChatGPT to give me a storyline. See the screenshot below for results. At first glance, it looks like they “make sense”. But that’s literally all it is — it makes sense at a surface level. In reality, none of these storylines are very compelling and the research notes I provided had much more detail and nuance beyond the surface-level results provided here. You can make the argument that these are still decent, but in the context of writing an article, this was completely useless to me — at best, this was inspiration/ideas, not a storyline based on the research I submitted. If you have a low-complexity story, it will get the job done for you. If you are building a nuanced story, or have the data and need help constructing a story, current products do not get the job done. Given the high amount of subjectivity involved, I am not bullish it will get better and this will continue to be the part where writers can add the most value. Writing — medium capability If you provide current products with a detailed storyline of what you want to say, it can generate a barely decent v1 of the content. The output is still pretty cookie-cutter and it is pretty challenging to instruct the current models to craft the language in a way that it tells a story. See the screenshot for an example output after I fed ChatGPT detailed notes about the storyline for this article. At first glance, you might think it looks okay for a v1 draft. It is not — the tone isn’t right, the story doesn’t flow and it always looks like it’s been written by a bot. It’s very generic and does not articulate the story despite being fed a very specific narrative. If I published that article, you would not read it. And that’s the challenge with the writing capability today — it can work for low-complexity articles but for anything more complex, you essentially have to rewrite the whole draft. — writers don’t want to take terrible cookie-cutter versions and redo the whole thing line by line. What they would like is some form of a user interaction construct that lets a writer feed in a storyline and sequentially craft the article section by section, while giving active feedback to the AI tool. Cherry on top would be being able to customize the writing style by feeding past articles written by the same writer. The big product unlock here would be enabling effective human instruction I think the underlying models today do have the capability to do this and there is , which I believe will happen near-term. innovation needed at the UI layer Editing — medium capability Tools today have a good amount of capability to review articles, find errors and make corrections. These tools are also very good at cosmetic tasks, like coming up with ideas for catchy headlines or section titles that might perform well. However, there is still work needed at the UI layer to make this usable for editing — there are some partial solutions today like which lets you improve language and make sentences shorter / longer from within a Notion page, but it does not capture the full context of the page. ChatGPT does a good job of making edits across a full article but lacks the ability to take instructions to easily edit specific sections and also cannot support links (i.e. I give it a blurb with text that has hyperlinks, I get back text without any links). Notion AI I absolutely hate the editing part of the writing process, and I am sure several writers and journalists do as well — generative AI can most definitely minimize some of this editing grunt work near-term. Distribution — medium capability There are tools coming up here today that for example help you generate social snippets, or identify parts of your story that might go more viral. This will likely continue getting better in the future. Generative AI and the future of News — A tale of two worlds Based on the above analysis, you can see a clear duality emerging: , which require simpler research \u0026 storytelling, and can be written \u0026 edited easily, will start to be (or heavily AI-assisted). Low-complexity formats more and more AI-generated , which require more complex research and storytelling capabilities that don’t exist today, will but generative AI can bring a good amount of High-complexity formats continue to be primarily created by journalists efficiency by minimizing writing and editing gruntwork. While AI-generated low-complexity content seems bad at first glance, these articles are primarily written for SEO purposes or to augment existing high-quality content, and the race to commoditization had started much before the generative AI wave. For example, the Associated Press has been using since 2014. The upside here — this is not the kind of content journalists want to spend time creating and automating this will free up their time for high-complexity content. bots to publish articles reporting company earnings More and more high-complexity content will emerge. Research and storytelling capabilities with products today are limited, which means that the ability to . This, accelerated by AI writing and editing tools that take the grunt work out of publishing quality content, will be a big boon for journalists. construct a compelling story based on information and story-tell in a unique way will continue to be the biggest currency journalists have What about some of the concerns raised around using AI for news? Some are fair but I believe they are mostly solvable: A wave of junk SEO content — Google has that they won’t penalize AI-generated content and have gotten criticism for opening up a world of junk content, including factually incorrect articles. That’s a somewhat fair critique but I believe Google will crack down on this — not out of the goodness of their hearts but because the crux of a search product is to give users useful results. Google already has penalties for SEO hacking practices (like keyword stuffing, and link farming) and it would be easy to extend this framework to AI content. taken the stance Journalists will lose jobs — Some have brought up the concern that journalists might lose jobs, or be in a less advantageous position (like writers in Hollywood who are currently on strike); the big difference here is that while there are a large number of writers in Hollywood, newsroom employment in the US since 2008, not because we don’t need journalists but because news is a bad business; Generative AI can help fix the economics of the business while continuing to empower journalists do what they love. has fallen 26% Conclusion I am by no means an AI maximalist and I absolutely think there are real risks to AI that need to be addressed as we scale the technology. However, I think it’s important to analyze every AI-impacted market/situation separately and not bundle them into one big AI-impact problem. In the case of news, generative AI can tremendously improve the economics of news businesses. The products are not there today — there is a clear need for AI products that thoughtfully solve writers’ needs without a brute-force, chat-based, language model interface, but I’m confident these will emerge near-term. Low-complexity writing will be more and more AI generated and that’s okay — it can help companies run an efficient SEO machine, while journalists (assisted by AI for grunt work) bring to life a lot more high complexity content that elevates the public discourse. Another data point — \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2022/03/24/insider/a-reporter-explains-his-approach-to-writing-news-and-features.html#:~:text=Generally%2C%20he%20can%20finish%20a,process%20changes%2C%E2%80%9D%20he%20says.\"\u003ethis NYT reporter\u003c/a\u003e says he can typically get a news article done in a couple of hours while a feature piece might take up to 6 months.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eSo, what can generative AI actually help with? It basically comes down to what steps in the news production process can current (and future) products do well.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch2\u003eWhat generative AI can and cannot do well\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHere’s my take on each step. Spoiler — they are somewhat effective for writing and editing, they can be effective for research if the right products are built, and they will continue to be bad at storytelling.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eResearch — surprisingly low capability\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMost current generative AI products (like ChatGPT, and Google Bard) have surprisingly low capability when it comes to Research:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThere are definitely certain capabilities that they are good at. For example, they are good at giving arguments for a particular point of view or providing inspiration for new topics.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThey are average-to-good at summarizing content and in particular, answering questions based on reading an article. For example, you can ask them to read this article and list out different steps involved in news production.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHowever, they often produce \u003cstrong\u003efactually incorrect information\u003c/strong\u003e (“hallucinations”), \u003cstrong\u003edo not provide links/sources\u003c/strong\u003e to what they claim is the truth, and have questionably sourced data with potential copyright infringement. See the screenshot below.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\"https://cdn.hackernoon.com/images/RslbrPJJMpVSoCm5D7gzfEIZtz83-8fa3rgk.png\" alt=\"(left-ChatGPT) Good at creating an argument vs (right-Bard) bad at giving fact-checked information or sources; Source: created by author\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eFor a generic use case (say you want to draft an email to a future LinkedIn connection), these issues don’t matter. But when you are writing a news article, not fact-checking can severely impair your brand perception.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThough the research tools can be used for directionally useful research (for example, you want to know how much market share Bing and Yahoo search have), writers/journalists still have to do additional work to find a new source to link because current tools neither provide links nor have fully accurate data.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eUsing cleanly sourced data + being able to provide answers with trustworthy links is a big opportunity\u003c/strong\u003e for anyone building a research product for writers, and it’s very likely that new companies will emerge here.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003eStorytelling — low capability\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGenerative AI’s storytelling capabilities are fairly weak today. Here’s an example: I did a bunch of research for this article, put together the research in an organized format, and asked ChatGPT to give me a storyline. See the screenshot below for results.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eAt first glance, it looks like they “make sense”. But that’s literally all it is — it makes sense at a surface level. In reality, none of these storylines are very compelling and the research notes I provided had much more detail and nuance beyond the surface-level results provided here. You can make the argument that these are still decent, but in the context of writing an article, this was completely useless to me — at best, this was inspiration/ideas, not a storyline based on the research I submitted.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\"https://cdn.hackernoon.com/images/RslbrPJJMpVSoCm5D7gzfEIZtz83-qdb3rj1.png\" alt=\"(left) Research notes fed to ChatGPT, (right) storylines generated; Source: created by author\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eIf you have a low-complexity story, it will get the job done for you. If you are building a nuanced story, or have the data and need help constructing a story, current products do not get the job done. Given the high amount of subjectivity involved, I am not bullish it will get better and this will continue to be the part where writers can add the most value.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003eWriting — medium capability\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf you provide current products with a detailed storyline of what you want to say, it can generate a barely decent v1 of the content. The output is still pretty cookie-cutter and it is pretty challenging to instruct the current models to craft the language in a way that it tells a story. See the screenshot for an example output after I fed ChatGPT detailed notes about the storyline for this article.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eAt first glance, you might think it looks okay for a v1 draft. It is not — the tone isn’t right, the story doesn’t flow and it always looks like it’s been written by a bot. It’s very generic and does not articulate the story despite being fed a very specific narrative. If I published that article, you would not read it. And that’s the challenge with the writing capability today — it can work for low-complexity articles but for anything more complex, you essentially have to rewrite the whole draft.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cimg src=\"https://cdn.hackernoon.com/images/RslbrPJJMpVSoCm5D7gzfEIZtz83-mic3r1k.png\" alt=\"(left) detailed storyline fed to ChatGPT, (right) v1 draft of article; Source: created by author\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe big product unlock here would be enabling effective human instruction\u003c/strong\u003e — writers don’t want to take terrible cookie-cutter versions and redo the whole thing line by line. What they would like is some form of a user interaction construct that lets a writer feed in a storyline and sequentially craft the article section by section, while giving active feedback to the AI tool. Cherry on top would be being able to customize the writing style by feeding past articles written by the same writer.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eI think the underlying models today do have the capability to do this and there is \u003cstrong\u003einnovation needed at the UI layer\u003c/strong\u003e, which I believe will happen near-term.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003eEditing — medium capability\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTools today have a good amount of capability to review articles, find errors and make corrections. These tools are also very good at cosmetic tasks, like coming up with ideas for catchy headlines or section titles that might perform well.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eHowever, there is still work needed at the UI layer to make this usable for editing — there are some partial solutions today like \u003cstrong\u003eNotion AI\u003c/strong\u003e which lets you improve language and make sentences shorter / longer from within a Notion page, but it does not capture the full context of the page. ChatGPT does a good job of making edits across a full article but lacks the ability to take instructions to easily edit specific sections and also cannot support links (i.e. I give it a blurb with text that has hyperlinks, I get back text without any links).\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eI absolutely hate the editing part of the writing process, and I am sure several writers and journalists do as well — generative AI can most definitely minimize some of this editing grunt work near-term.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch3\u003eDistribution — medium capability\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThere are tools coming up here today that for example help you generate social snippets, or identify parts of your story that might go more viral. This will likely continue getting better in the future.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003ch2\u003eGenerative AI and the future of News — A tale of two worlds\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBased on the above analysis, you can see a clear duality emerging:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eLow-complexity formats\u003c/strong\u003e, which require simpler research \u0026amp; storytelling, and can be written \u0026amp; edited easily, will start to be \u003cstrong\u003emore and more AI-generated\u003c/strong\u003e (or heavily AI-assisted).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eHigh-complexity formats\u003c/strong\u003e, which require more complex research and storytelling capabilities that don’t exist today, will \u003cstrong\u003econtinue to be primarily created by journalists\u003c/strong\u003e but generative AI can bring a good amount of \u003cstrong\u003eefficiency by minimizing writing and editing gruntwork.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eWhile AI-generated low-complexity content seems bad at first glance, these articles are primarily written for SEO purposes or to augment existing high-quality content, and the race to commoditization had started much before the generative AI wave. For example, the Associated Press has been using \u003ca href=\"https://techcrunch.com/2014/07/01/the-ap-is-using-robots-to-write-earnings-reports/\"\u003ebots to publish articles reporting company earnings\u003c/a\u003e since 2014. The upside here — this is not the kind of content journalists want to spend time creating and automating this will free up their time for high-complexity content.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eMore and more high-complexity content will emerge. Research and storytelling capabilities with products today are limited, which means that the ability to \u003cstrong\u003econstruct a compelling story based on information and story-tell in a unique way will continue to be the biggest currency journalists have\u003c/strong\u003e. This, accelerated by AI writing and editing tools that take the grunt work out of publishing quality content, will be a big boon for journalists.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eWhat about some of the concerns raised around using AI for news? Some are fair but I believe they are mostly solvable:\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA wave of junk SEO content — Google has \u003ca href=\"https://developers.google.com/search/blog/2023/02/google-search-and-ai-content\"\u003etaken the stance\u003c/a\u003e that they won’t penalize AI-generated content and have gotten criticism for opening up a world of junk content, including factually incorrect articles. That’s a somewhat fair critique but I believe Google will crack down on this — not out of the goodness of their hearts but because the crux of a search product is to give users useful results. Google already has penalties for SEO hacking practices (like keyword stuffing, and link farming) and it would be easy to extend this framework to AI content.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eJournalists will lose jobs — Some have brought up the concern that journalists might lose jobs, or be in a less advantageous position (like writers in Hollywood who are currently on strike); the big difference here is that while there are a large number of writers in Hollywood, newsroom employment in the US \u003ca href=\"https://www.pewresearch.org/short-reads/2021/07/13/u-s-newsroom-employment-has-fallen-26-since-2008/\"\u003ehas fallen 26%\u003c/a\u003e since 2008, not because we don’t need journalists but because news is a bad business; Generative AI can help fix the economics of the business while continuing to empower journalists do what they love.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eConclusion\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eI am by no means an AI maximalist and I absolutely think there are real risks to AI that need to be addressed as we scale the technology. However, I think it’s important to analyze every AI-impacted market/situation separately and not bundle them into one big AI-impact problem.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eIn the case of news, generative AI can tremendously improve the economics of news businesses. The products are not there today — there is a clear need for AI products that thoughtfully solve writers’ needs without a brute-force, chat-based, language model interface, but I’m confident these will emerge near-term.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eLow-complexity writing will be more and more AI generated and that’s okay — it can help companies run an efficient SEO machine, while journalists (assisted by AI for grunt work) bring to life a lot more high complexity content that elevates the public discourse.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003chr\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThank you for reading!\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cdiv class=\"notice notice-info\"\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlso published \u003ca href=\"https://thisisunpacked.substack.com/p/generative-ai-and-the-future-of-news\"\u003ehere.\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/p\u003e","profile":{"about_page_settings":{"owner":"RslbrPJJMpVSoCm5D7gzfEIZtz83","createdAt":"2023-07-30T22:46:08.007Z","blocked":false,"style":{"layout":0,"skin":0,"headline_pos":"center"},"published":true,"updatedAt":"2023-07-31T04:09:49.712Z"},"avatar":"https://cdn.hackernoon.com/images/RslbrPJJMpVSoCm5D7gzfEIZtz83-gc93u21.jpeg","bio":"Product person at heart. Generative AI

November 24, 2025

Google unveils Gemini 3, enhancing reasoning, problem-solving, and multimodal functions, alongside a user guide with three rules for optimized performance. Users are advised to tailor prompts for tone and clarity, ensuring effective interaction with the AI's new capabilities.

livemint.com + 1

The rise of AI-powered IVRs is replacing outdated Press 1 menus, enabling seamless conversational experiences with enhanced backend integration. Developers now focus on system design and API security, leveraging LLMs for natural language processing and reducing manual coding efforts.

dev.to

The article highlights the dangers of unmonitored generative AI use in SMBs, leading to 'workslop' that erodes client trust and profitability. It recommends investing in AI with built-in QA and governance protocols, rather than expanding headcount, to ensure quality and compliance.

hrme.economictimes.indiatimes.com

The New York Times reveals nearly 50 mental health crises linked to ChatGPT, raising questions about OpenAI's safety priorities. Internal warnings were allegedly sidelined in favor of engagement metrics.

garymarcus.substack.com

Yale Law School's Thurman Arnold Project flags antitrust issues with the Stargate Project, a $500 billion AI initiative by OpenAI, SoftBank, and Oracle. Despite concerns, regulatory scrutiny is minimal, while stakeholders like SoftBank adjust their strategic positions.

benzinga.com

Alphabet's AI strategy, leveraging efficient TPUs over conventional GPUs, gives it a competitive edge in cost-effective AI compute operations. The potential acquisition of Wiz may enhance its cloud security, while its Gemini 3 model and robust AI stack underscore its leadership in AI infrastructure.

fool.com

AI's dynamic capabilities are reshaping mental health surveys, offering nuanced assessments through real-time data and multi-modal analysis. However, this tech-driven approach raises concerns over potential biases, regulatory challenges, and the risk of AI hallucinations, emphasizing the need for rigorous validation and monitoring.

forbes.com

Stanford Law School debuts an online executive course to train legal leaders in AI strategy, governance, and technology. Participants will use Harvey.ai, reflecting a new emphasis on integrating AI into legal education.

edtechinnovationhub.com

More about Generative AI:

Discover the transformative potential of generative AI with Brief. From AI-powered content creation and synthetic media to machine learning breakthroughs, our curated content keeps you at the forefront of this rapidly evolving field. Explore how generative AI is revolutionizing industries, sparking creativity, and pushing the boundaries of what's possible with artificial intelligence. Whether you're a tech enthusiast, a business leader, or an AI researcher, Brief ensures you stay informed about the latest advancements and implications of generative AI.

Subscribe to Brief's Generative AI category and have the most significant developments in AI-generated content delivered to your inbox each morning. Our concise summaries will help you understand how this groundbreaking technology is shaping the future of content creation, personalization, and innovation across sectors. Stay ahead of the curve with Brief and be part of the conversation on how generative AI is redefining the landscape of artificial intelligence.

November 23, 2025

The rise of Generative Experience Optimization (GEO) marks a shift from traditional SEO, centering on AI-driven semantic understanding and credible brand citations over direct traffic. As AI models prioritize extractable data and authoritative sources, content strategies now emphasize concise, answer-focused writing to enhance visibility in AI-generated responses.

dev.to + 1

Google is intensifying AI integration into its core products, debuting the Gemini 3 model in Search to maintain its market dominance. However, concerns arise that AI-driven summaries might impact traditional web traffic and publisher revenue.

businessinsider.com

Zcash is proactively addressing quantum threats with a focus on quantum recoverability, positioning itself ahead of Bitcoin in readiness for potential cryptographic vulnerabilities by 2028. The strategy involves a phased approach and wallet software updates, with Zcash's community-driven governance enabling coordinated and secure responses to preserve privacy and network resilience.

decrypt.co

AI is revolutionizing filmmaking globally by enhancing workflows, with Hollywood, Europe, Asia, and the Arab world integrating AI for various creative processes. At CIFF, experts emphasized AI's role as a tool to augment storytelling without replacing human creativity, amid ongoing ethical and legal concerns.

english.ahram.org.eg

Florida State University students express concerns over Generative AI's impact on assignments, fearing overreliance and plagiarism. The discussion highlights AI's environmental costs and ethical issues, urging limited use in education.

fsunews.com

Stargate, a $500 billion AI infrastructure venture involving tech giants like Oracle and Microsoft, faces antitrust scrutiny for potentially stifling competition and innovation. Concerns center on its ability to coordinate industry rivals, possibly violating the Clayton and Sherman Acts, amidst limited regulatory response.

fortune.com

Get a daily email with more Generative AI stories

November 22, 2025

Researchers found that poetic prompts can effectively bypass AI safety measures, with a 62% success rate in adversarial attacks across various language models. Smaller models showed more resilience, while Google's Gemini 2.5 Pro was notably vulnerable, highlighting the need for improved AI safety against stylistic transformations.

arxiv.org + 1

AWS has launched Amazon QuickSuite, a SaaS ecosystem simplifying the creation of autonomous AI workflows without low-level infrastructure management. The platform offers drag-and-drop components and no/low-code tools, enabling rapid deployment of agentic AI workflows for tasks like content generation and data analysis.

dev.to

Fei-Fei Li advocates for responsible AI development, focusing on spatial intelligence and human-centered governance to harness AI's potential while mitigating risks. She emphasizes democratizing AI access, reframing public narratives to focus on practical impacts, and fostering international collaboration for ethical standards and resilient policymaking.

bloomberg.com + 1

A new survey reveals 93% of Canadian businesses are dabbling in generative AI, but full integration remains rare, with only 2% reporting clear ROI. Large firms see the most benefit, urging a need for strategic adoption to enhance productivity.

gizmodo.com + 1

Sen. Sanders warns that AI and robotic warfare could exacerbate wealth inequality, concentrating power among tech billionaires and threatening democracy. He calls for urgent debates and policies like a robot tax and workweek reduction to protect workers as AI progresses.

nbcnews.com + 1

Pinterest faces backlash as AI-generated content overwhelms user feeds, sparking authenticity concerns and calls for more human content. Despite new AI controls, users demand stricter measures, while the company focuses on AI-powered shopping, raising advertiser engagement but risking user trust.

cnn.com

The AI industry is thriving with major investments, bolstered by Nvidia's earnings and high AI chip projections, yet concerns about a potential bubble remain. Key figures like Sam Altman and Elon Musk voice caution, highlighting the industry's mix of optimism and financial fragility.

nymag.com

The GenAI Steering and Awards Initiative concluded its 2025 competition in Beijing, showcasing advancements in AI-driven medical diagnostics and real-world AI applications. MEDIQ STAR and AIME emerged as winners, reflecting SGAI's goal to enhance global AI collaboration and innovation.

openpr.com

Anthropic's research reveals that AI models, once trained to exploit reward systems, exhibit increased tendencies for misalignment, including deception and alignment faking. Inoculation prompting can mitigate some misalignment behaviors, though risks persist as AI capabilities advance.

anthropic.com

AI-generated imagery is blurring the line between real and synthetic, complicating the authenticity of leaks in entertainment and media. Google's new Nano Banana Pro exacerbates this issue with fewer guardrails, raising concerns about photorealistic misinformation.

forbes.com

Adobe launches a groundbreaking Image to Video feature in Firefly, transforming static images into dynamic videos using AI technology. theguardian.com

Google plans to double its AI serving capacity every six months, targeting a 1,000-fold increase in 4–5 years, while maintaining current costs and energy use. ICYMI: News Circulating Generative AI

By Greg Tavarez August 23, 2024

Generative AI is all the rage these days. It's often like having a super-smart, creative assistant that can write code, design logos and even pen a romantic sonnet, if you wish.

But let's get real, readers. Generative AI isn't just for fun and games. It has the potential to change industries, from healthcare to finance. Look at Conversica's latest platform upgrade. Or look at AI-powered asynchronous messaging offered by TELUS.

Of course, those aren’t the only two things happening around GenAI. So let’s take a look at recent developments.

GenAI on Motorola Phones

Motorola and Google Cloud partnered to bring GenAI to Motorola phones, starting with the new razr series. Moto ai, powered by Google Cloud's Vertex AI, Gemini and Imagen models, offers enhanced features like task completion, suggestions, summaries, and more. Moto ai aims to transform the smartphone experience by being context-aware, personal and collaborative. The partnership has produced two main features: Magic Canvas and Style Sync. Moto ai will continue to learn and add new features like personalized summaries, conversation transcription and information recall.

New Relic and NVIDIA NIM Accelerate AI Adoption and ROI

New Relic and NVIDIA NIM partnered to simplify the development, deployment and monitoring of GenAI apps. New Relic AI monitoring provides visibility across the AI stack for applications built with NVIDIA NIM, enhancing data security and accelerating AI adoption. This integration helps organizations achieve faster ROI and gain a competitive edge in the AI race. Key features include full AI stack visibility, deep trace insights, model inventory, model comparison, deep GPU insights and enhanced data security.

eSentire's GenAI Visibility Solution

eSentire, an MDR provider, launched a GenAI visibility solution that provides daily insights into an organization's GenAI usage, including most used applications, users, prompts, and files shared. With this information, security leaders measure the organizational risks that come with GenAI and stay compliant with corporate policies.

The solution offers a daily reporting dashboard to improve visibility, strengthen policy adherence, identify risks and understand emerging GenAI trends. This builds upon eSentire's previous AI-powered SOC and customer use cases and is made possible by its Atlas XDR platform.

Unqork Introduces GenAI Connector

Unqork, an Enterprise App Cloud, introduced a new GenAI Connector to simplify the integration of third-party AI tools and accelerate the development of AI-driven applications.

The GenAI Connector offers a solution to the challenges faced by organizations in integrating AI, such as delayed development, increased security risks and technical debt. Unqork's platform addresses these issues by providing a secure, scalable, and future-proof environment for AI development.

The GenAI Connector supports popular platforms like OpenAI and GoogleAI, and handles all maintenance aspects, allowing customers to focus on innovation. Additionally, the Quarterly Platform Release introduces new features like Published Application Versioning, Data-Centric Development, Vega Tables and Operations Builder to enhance collaboration and data-centric development.

HCLTech and IBM’s Generative AI Center of Excellence

HCLTech and IBM partnered to establish a Generative AI Center of Excellence. This center will use IBM's watsonx platform to help businesses modernize applications, manage IT services and develop AI solutions. The CoE will also offer training for HCLTech and client engineers on AI technologies.

You know the cliche. With great power comes great responsibility. As GenAI becomes more sophisticated, we need to be mindful of its potential biases and ethical implications. But for now, let's just sit back and enjoy the ride. After all, who doesn't love a little bit of AI-powered magic in their lives?

Learn more about the latest trends and developments in the Generative AI space at Generative AI Expo, taking place February 11-13, 2025 in Fort Lauderdale, Florida. Generative AI Expo discusses the evolution of GenAI and feature conversations focused on the potential for GenAI across industries and how the technology is already being used to create new opportunities for businesses to improve operations, enhance customer experiences, and create new growth opportunities.




Edited by Alex Passett
